title-group.article-title: The Berlin Stock Exchange in Imperial Germany: A Market for New Technology?

abstract.p: Analyzing 474 cases of firms going public in the German capital between 1892 and 1913, we show that innovative firms could rely on the Berlin stock market as a source of financing. Our data also reveal that initial public offerings (IPO) of innovative firms were characterized by particularly low underpricing, comparatively high first trading prices, and no long-run underperformance. We interpret these empirical results as evidence for the surprising fact that in the period of the Second Industrial Revolution the Berlin stock exchange was already a well-functioning market for new technology.

p.mixed-citation: Historical Archives of the Deutsche Bank (HADB, SG 31-10).
